item.title: Train Dreams, 2025 - ★★★★★
item.description: Absolutely floored by the discipline on display here. the gaze brings a beauty out of impermanence, witnessing the west decompose and bloom with detached patience that somehow feels radically intimate.
item.dc:creator: m

item.title: A Poet, 2025 - ★★★★
item.description: Damn, the screenplay is tight. A character study that sees further than i thought it could. For almost the first half, i never think it had anything else left to offer, im glad i was wrong.
item.dc:creator: m

item.title: Arcadia, 2024 - ★★★½
item.description: Quite surprised to see this unfold as procedural (at first) — austere in a way they setup the opening — then drifted into metaphysical drama about the living and the dead. Zois’s vision is expansive, though at times the film’s attention strays toward side characters whose presence feels unnecessary to explore and rather atmospheric than fully integrated into the main narrative.
item.dc:creator: m

item.title: A House of Dynamite, 2025 - ★★
item.description: I do like A House of Dynamite to some extent. Bigelow visualizes deterrence as an ontology of paralysis, states acting and fearing within architectures they pretend to command. But that’s it. The discourse feels exhausted, the moral calculus rehearsed to the point of inertia. Feels like we're circling the same language of control and collapse that no longer shocks.
item.dc:creator: m

item.title: Citizen Kane, 1941 - ★★★★½
item.description: Klikfilm Matinee. i dont think this is the new 4K restoration
item.dc:creator: m

item.title: It Was Just an Accident, 2025 - ★★★★★
item.description:
After what happened to him over the past few years, it makes perfect sense that Jafar Panahi's latest work shifts his cinema into the sharp territory of the political thriller. The formal and conceptual work of the film is primarily enacted within the mobile heterotopia of Vahid's van, a space that reconfigures the semiotics of the Panahian automobile from vessel of freedom and liberty into crucible for an impossible juridical process. Panahi stages an unforgiving dialectic between physical mobility and psychic enclosure. While the vehicle travel the urban landscape, its interior remains hermetically sealed, making the exterior world almost unreachable.

This spatial logic constitutes a specific political subject-as-provisional collective forged through shared memory of trauma whose discourse-the dominant action of the film-transcodes raw impulse of vengeance into fraught, extra-legal procedure. In this regard, a metaphor of the temporality of trauma—the continuous, circular motion of a van mimes the cycle of repetition where every attempt to move forward only deepens the psychic stasis.

The Suffocating, close framing transposes the van into more than its confined space; It's an existential state, specified by the traces of violence carved into body and mind, for which there is no distance nor route of escape.
item.dc:creator: m

item.title: 2024 End Year List: Documentary
item.description:
This year, I decided to separate fiction and documentary films in my end-of-year list. So much has happened in the world, and just ranking them as personal favorites felt wrong—it seemed to downplay the urgency of the issues we’re facing.

  • No Other Land

    There is no other documentary you need to watch more than this one. Against the backdrop of the ongoing Gaza genocide, No Other Land offers a searing portrayal of perpetual colonialism and the brutal realities faced by Palestinian villagers in Masafer Yatta. The film’s raw, unflinching narrative exposes the structural violence and relentless demolitions inflicted upon these communities while celebrating their unyielding spirit of resistance.

  • Soundtrack to a Coup d'Etat

    Through archival footage and an chaoting editing, Grimonprez navigates this complex episode of the start of Pax Americana order. His approach to storytelling mirrors the improvisational nature of jazz, where rhythms of tension and release echo the political upheavals of the time. Despite the intensity and fragmented nature of the visuals, Grimonprez ensures that the documentary never loses sight of its central message. The chaotic flow of images, sounds, and voices comes together in a way that distills the heart of this historical moment, making it comprehensible even to those unfamiliar with cold-war international politics.

  • Monisme

    I liked the post-colonial approach in Monisme, remind me much of Weerasethakul's Memoria (2021). What struck me most was how Rizaldi uses the figure of the mystic as a counter-narrative to the modern, scientific, rational Western worldview. Rizaldi doesn’t present this indigenous worldview in opposition to the scientist’s rationalism in a simplistic, binary way. Instead, both perspectives coexist within the film’s polyphonic structure, each presenting a legitimate form of knowledge, without privileging one over the other.

  • Dahomey

    As I wrote this excerpt, i realize the movies on my list are underlined an ongoing relevance of the post-colonial movement and its exploration of the lasting effects of colonialism. Each film, in its unique way, speaks to the complexities of power, identity, and on this, restitution,

    On Dahomey, Mati Diop brings a poetic sensibility to this weighty topic, elevating the narrative beyond legal or political debates into something far more human and profound. The objects being returned represent the stories, identities, and legacies of a people who were once colonized and stripped of their history.

  • The Gullspång Miracle

    Encapsulating the notion that life is stranger than fiction, it employs layered narratives that juggle the complexities of identity construction. Each twist and piece of information could becomes its own intriguing story. Maria Fredriksson’s direction has this uncanny ability to pull you into the mystery, and by the end, I couldn’t stop thinking about how fragile our understanding of “truth” really is. This is the kind of documentary that lingers in my mind long after the credits roll.

    Human stories, as this illustrates, can be both fascinating and terrifying.

  • Afternoons of Solitude
  • I'm Not Everything I Want to Be
  • Ryuichi Sakamoto: Opus
  • The Night Won't End
  • Trains

...plus 1 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
